DOC.HEAD: Great Northern Claims Takeover Would Prevent Needed Expenditures
DOC.TEXT: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. said Wednesday in federal court that needed capital investments at its Maine operations could not be made and that anti-competitive practices would result if Georgia-Pacific Corp. is successful in its $3.8 billion takeover attempt. The testimony came in the opening day of a hearing on Great Northern's request for an injunction to block the unfriendly takeover. Great Northern claims antitrust laws would be violated if the two forest products companies merged. U.S. District Judge Warren W. Eginton set aside 14 days for the hearing. The chairman of Great Northern, William R. Laidig, testified about the Norwalk-based company's plans for $2.5 billion in capital investments and acquisitions in Maine over the next five years. Laidig, during questioning by the company's attorney, said Georgia-Pacific would be so laden with debt if it were successful in the takeover that it could not possibly carry out the capital plans. The takeover would result in anti-competitive practices in southern pulpwood markets and in the national market for paper used in personal bank checks, Great Northern also asserted. Georgia-Pacific's chief executive officer, T. Marshall Hahn, said outside the courtroom that the projected cash flow after a merger of the two companies would be adequate ``even in a financial crisis'' to finance needed capital expenditures. ``It's an old-fashioned combination of two strong industrial companies,'' Hahn said, calling Great Northern's claims ``transparent nonsense.'' ``There is no junk debt involved,'' he said. Great Northern has calculated the resulting debt would total $4.5 billion. Attorneys for Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific said a merger would increase efficiency. As of Friday, 73.4 percent of Great Northern stockholders tendered their shares under Georgia-Pacific's $63-a-share offer, Stapleton said. The takeover battle is also being waged in Maine, where Great Northern is incorporated. Georgia-Pacific is challenging anti-takeover provisions in Great Northern's bylaws, as well as Maine's corporate takeover law, which forces hostile suitors to wait five years before merging with a targeted company.
